results.title: Our potential allies
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
‘Our Potential Allies’ is an intuitive and ironic critique of Eurocentric belief-systems founded upon the dichotomy of self (the West) and the Other. Callas appears on the left monitor in black and white facial paint – the so-called ‘mask of primitivism’ – while compressed news imagery appears upon the right. Facial gestures are enacted by the artist seemingly in response to the voice-over (instructions issued by General Douglas MacArthur to American soldiers fighting in Papua New Guinea during the Second World War) or to imagery on the right monitor. Questions of intent – a constant theme throughout Callas’ career – are thus raised in relation to the creation of apparently random meaning.
Notes by Rachel Kent, reprinted courtesy of the author and d/Lux Media Arts.

results.title: Marco Solo
results.creator_credit: VCA Film and Television School, University of Melbourne and Adrian Bosich
results.brief_description:
Poor Marco. Accidentally born into an overcrowded Australian-Italian household, he is relegated to his parents’ bedroom. Nine years later, armed with a vivid imagination, an obsession with Dame Edna, and a warped sense of Catholicism, Marco searches for a space of his own. Cast includes Joseph Sollena, Robert Urban, Helen Nicholas, Irini Pappas, Maria Diele.
‘Marco Solo’ screened at many film festivals, including Palm Springs and London International Film Festival.

results.title: Tal Farlow
results.brief_description: Jazz guitarist Tal Farlow provides the background music to Lye’s final film, which, although begun in the 1950s, was not recommenced until the 1980s. Unfortunately he died before completing it. It contains vertical white scratches as well as geometric white scratches on black. It was completed by Lye’s assistant Steve Jones under the supervision of Ann Lye. Supported in part by a grant from the Queen Elizabeth II Arts Council of New Zealand.

results.title: Free radicals
results.brief_description:
A primitive kinetic dance of white lines and angles meticulously scratched onto black and white film over an 8 month period and then edited and retrospectively matched with an African field tape of the Bagirmi tribe. The title is a reference to modern physics, ‘free radicals’ being particles of energy. The original version was a major award winner at the Experimental Film Competition at the 1958 Brussels World Fair. This revised version was a reworking of the
original by Lye in 1979, with financial assistance from
the New Zealand Film Commission. He deleted approximately 1 min. from his first version, made in 1958.

results.title: The Age of change
results.creator_credit: Ivan Gaal and Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development
results.brief_description: Looks at the impact of technological change on the Melbourne newspaper ‘The Age’ and considers this change in terms of its effect on the people involved. Highlights the increasing competition at the desk of reporters and editors from electronic information systems, and the impact of technology on the once labour-intensive area of printing.

results.title: Celebrations
results.creator_credit: Ivan Gaal and Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre
results.brief_description: A documentary film presenting six different and authentic celebrations involving people in the multicultural community of Melbourne. Depicts an Aboriginal dance showing body decoration preparation, an Indonesian Muslim wedding celebration, an Australian child’s birthday party, a Greek nameday party, Christmas festivities and a Northern Italian Christmas celebration. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: A Day at the Ascot Vale School No 2608
results.brief_description: Portrays the outdoor life at a school in the 1920s. Shows school dress, assembly, physical training, organised dancing and games. Junior Red Cross activities, Mothers Club and School Committee.

results.title: The Place Across the River
results.creator_credit: David Greig, John Richardson and Kestrel Film Productions
results.brief_description: Explore the rich history of Melbourne through the National Gallery of Victoria site in St Kilda Road, Melbourne, via its various uses, as a circus site in 1887 to the landmark cultural centre it became. Mixes found footage, stills and contemporary footage.

results.title: Look after your bicycle! [Junior Road Safety Series Episode 3]
results.creator_credit: Henry Lewes, Malcolm Otton, Martin Williams, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Martin Williams Films
results.brief_description: The setting of the film is a bicycle repair shop, presided over by a mechanic who is surrounded by bicycles waiting to be repaired. Direct teaching is avoided by making various parts of the bicycle talk, in children’s voices. They tell the repair man about the treatment they have received from their riders and the accidents and near-misses in which they have been involved. As they talk, scenes show how badly maintained bicycles can be the cause of accidents.
